text:
Irving Place, east side, from 18th Street to 20th Street and Gramercy Park. 78 and 76 Irving Place, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of 19th Street, were erected around 1900 on the site of old 4story houses.
March, 1909.
9irown Brothers.

Irving Place, west side, from 18th Street to 20th Street and Gramercy
Park.
The four houses at and adjoining the N.W. corner of 18th Street are 65-67-e9-71 Irving Place; 67-o9 are to be demolished a year after this picture, and a 12-story loft building will rise on the site. The shops on Irving Place at and adjoining the S.W. coner of 19th Street are quite neW; for years there was a gap. occupied by the back yard of 122 East 19th Street, the corner building. Behind 67-9 Irving Place may be seen the roof of the new 12-story National
Arts Club, 14-13 Gramercy Park (South).
About 1927 the old house at 18 Gramercy Park, on the S.W. corner of 20th Street and Irving Place, will be replaced by the 17-ptory Farkside Hotel; and after 1930 the rest of the block, old 81-83 Irving Place, at and adjoining the N.W. coner of 19th Street, will
be replaced by a 16-story apartment house.
March, 1909.
Brown Brothers.

18th Street at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Irving Place, showing the former Huyler Chocolate and Cocoa Works. The corner building is the oldest part of the factory, dating back to around 1879. The taller double building at 132-36 East 18th Street was built about 1908. Beyond it may be seen "The Stuyvesant", at 142 East 18th Street, one of the first apartment houses built in the United
States.
July 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
A view showing complete demolition of the former candy factory. Shown across the empty lot is the rear and side of No. 129 East 17th
Street apartment house.
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

18th Street at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Irving Place, showing the former Huyler Chocolate and Cocoa Works. The corner building is the oldest part of the factory, dating back to around 1879. The taller double building at 132-36 East 18th Street was built about 1908. Beyond it may be seen "The Stuyvesant", at 142 East 18th Street, one of the first apartment houses built in the United
States.
July 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
A view showing complete demolition of the former candy factory. Shown across the empty lot is the rear and side of No. 129 East 17th
Street apartment house.
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
East 18th Street, south side, east from Irving Place to Third Ave. Shown under demolition at the S.E. corner of Irving Place, is the Huyler
Chocolate Co. Building.
November 9, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same; after complete clearance. Note the 18th Street Station
of the Third Ave. Elevated Line.
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
East 18th Street, south side, east from Irving Place to Third Ave. Shown under demolition at the S.E. corner of Irving Place, is the Huyler
Chocolate Co. Building.
November 9, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same; after complete clearance. Note the 18th Street Station
of the Third Ave. Elevated Line.
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

East 18th Street, west from Irving Place.
September 2, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.
NEG. #4683

63-55 Irving Place, at, adjoining and south of the S.W. corner of East 18th Street, as seen across clearance at the S.E. corner (former site of Huyler's Chocolate Co. Building). The 6-store building is No. 63 and was an exchange of the N.Y. Telephone Co.; they having vacated the premises about 1936. The 20-story buildings shown, form the western side of this block and are the Guardian Life Insurance Co, of America Building and the Clarendon Building. They are located on the east side of Fourth Ave., at the N.E. corner of 17th and the S.E. corner of 18th Streets respectively.
December 23, 1936.
P.L. Sperr.

Irving Place, at the S.E. corner of East 18th Street. Shown under demolition is the Huyler Chocolate Co. Building, a landmark here since 1885. On the extreme right, appears a portion of the Washington Irving High School for Girls.
November 9, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

Irving Place, west side, north from No. 73, a point midway between East 18th and 19th Streets, across the latter to Gramercy Park. North of the Park this thoroughfare becomes Lexington Ave.; upon which appears
the shadowy outline of the Chrysler Building.
August 7, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

Irving Place, west side, north from East 18th Street to Gramercy
Park South (East 20th Street).
July 1937.
George D. Chinn.

East 18th Street, east from Irving Place, showing mainly buildings on the north side of this thoroughfare, extending to Third Avenue. At that point appears the "El" station of the transportation facility identified with Third Avenue. Across same are the buildings and water tanks of the chemical firm, Elmer & Amend. Note to the right the cleared lot where formerly stood the Huyler Confectionery Co. plant. The side wall exposed by same is the westerly side of the well known "first" apartment house, No. 142 East 18th Street.
July 19, 1939
J. L. Sperr
